qas.question: What is an example of a regulatory region of a gene that does not have to close to the coding sequence?
Why do some regulatory regions of a gene not have to be close to the coding sequence?

answers.text: because the intervening DNA can be looped out to bring the gene and its regulatory region into proximity

qas.question: What part of a gene can be much larger than its exons?
How do regulatory regions on different chromosomes operate in order to allow regions on different chromosomes to come into contact with one another?
Where can regulatory regions be found?

context: Defining exactly what section of a DNA sequence comprises a gene is difficult. Regulatory regions of a gene such as <a0_0>enhancers<a0_0/> do not necessarily have to be close to the coding sequence on the linear molecule <a1_0>because the intervening DNA can be looped out to bring the gene and its regulatory region into proximity<a1_0/>. Similarly, <a2_0>a gene's introns<a2_0/> can be much larger than its exons. Regulatory regions can even be on entirely <a4_0>different chromosomes<a4_0/> and operate <a3_0>in trans<a3_0/> to allow regulatory regions on one chromosome to come in contact with target genes on another chromosome.
